###**Description:**

This Appendix contains the code to:
1) Generate maps of the surveyed sites 
2) Generate extirpations vs introductions spatial map
3) Explore features of the data
4) Calculate the area of each basin that contains more than 3 sites
5) Compute the species' accumulation curves & estimated gamma diversity

<p>&nbsp;</p>

#### **Area of basins: **
```{r, echo=TRUE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
basins <- split(NDT67, f=NDT67$DrainageBasinE)
basins_pointsKm2 <- lapply(basins, function(x) {SpatialPoints(cbind(x$Longitude,x$Latitude), proj4string=CRS('+proj=longlat +ellps=WGS84 +datum=WGS84 +no_defs')) %>% sp::spTransform(., CRS("+proj=merc +lon_0=0 +k=1 +x_0=0 +y_0=0 +ellps=WGS84 +datum=WGS84 +units=km +no_defs"))})
basins_areaKm2 <- as.data.frame(do.call(rbind, lapply(basins_pointsKm2, function(x) {gArea(gConvexHull(x))})))
names(basins_areaKm2) <- "areakm2"

# Remove those basins with 1 or 2 sites only.
round(basins_areaKm2, 0) %>%
  filter(areakm2>0) %>% # Basins with one or two sites only
  kbl() %>%
  kable_styling() # 9 basins
```

```{r, echo=TRUE, results=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
sum(NDT67$`RatioFound/Expected`[NDT67$CountNonNat2005==0]==1)    # 7 (preserved native + no nonative)


sort(unique(NDT67$CatalogNumbers))

sort(unique(NDT67$Comments))
```
<p>&nbsp;</p>
The dataset contains historical and contemporary data from 67 sites in 19 drainage basins. These sites represent different bodies of water, both lentic & lotic. The number of sites x basin ranges from 1 (lakes) to 10. Ten of the basins are represented by only 1 or 2 sites, on the other nine by more than 3.
In the historical period, the richness of native species ranges from 1 to 17 species. The richness of non-native fish is mostly 0 but there are 4 non-native fish that appear in a few sites.
In the contemporary period, the richness of native fish species ranges from 0 to 9 and the richness of non-natives ranges from 0 to 6. There are no native fish in 7 sites, and no non-native fish in 30 sites including those where no fish life was found. The native assemblage is preserved in 13 sites, 7 of which contain no introduced fishes.
The historical collections are reconstructed with catalog records from the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology and the United States National Museum (Smithsonian). These records are mostly reported by Miller, but also other authors. The date of these collections ranges from 1891 to 1986 and therefore the historical period includes data that was collected in different time windows over a period of ~ 100 years.

#### **Richness: **

```{r, echo=TRUE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
listComms <- list(HNC, HNB, ContNE)
listCommsL <- lapply(listComms, function(x){gather(x, key="Species", value="S", -c(1:2))})
S <- lapply(listCommsL, function(x) {x <- x %>% group_by(SiteName) %>% summarise(S=sum(S))})

# NÂº sites with S=1, S=2 or S>3:
S1 <- lapply(S, function(x) {x <- subset(x, x$S==1)}) # HC: 19, HB: 7 & Cont: 4
S2 <- lapply(S, function(x) {x <- subset(x, x$S==2)}) # HC: 2, HB: 8 & Cont: 14
S3 <- lapply(S, function(x) {x <- subset(x, x$S>3)})  # HC: 34, HB: 44, Cont: 27
```

#### **Species accumulation curves (Survey data 53): **

```{r Fig1, echo=TRUE, results=TRUE, fig.height=7, fig.width=6}
plot_dirSM <- "C:/Users/Usuario/Documents/PHD/CHAPTER3_Analyses/DataAnalysis&Visualization_FishCentralMexico/C_CoreAnalysisPlots" # Dir to save main plots
list_nat_mat <- list("HNC"=as.matrix(HNC[,c(3:ncol(HNC))]), "HNB"=as.matrix(HNB[,c(3:ncol(HNB))]))
listComms_mat <- lapply(listComms, function(x){as.matrix(x[,c(3:ncol(x))])})
names(listComms_mat) <- c("Historical Conservative", "Historical Broad", "Contemporary")

# Historical native data:
listSpecaccumNat <- lapply(list_nat_mat, function(x) {x <- specaccum(x, method="random", permutations=1000)})
listSpecaccumNat <- lapply(listSpecaccumNat, function(x) {x <- data.frame(cbind(x$sites, x$richness, x$sd))
names(x) <-c("Sites", "Richness", "Sd");x})

list_plotsNat <- list()
for (i in 1:length(listSpecaccumNat)){
  dt <- listSpecaccumNat[[i]]
  x <- names(listSpecaccumNat)[[i]]
  SpCurves <- ggplot(data=dt, aes(y=Richness, x=Sites)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymin=(Richness-2*Sd), ymax=(Richness+2*Sd)),alpha=0.2)+ # Does a bit of a weird thing for low levels of richness
  ylim(c(0,100))+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks=c(0,20,40,60,80,100), 
                   labels=c("0","20","40","60","80","100"))+
  labs(title=x)+
  theme_classic()+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    legend.title=element_text(size=14), 
    legend.text=element_text(size=12))
list_plotsNat[[i]] <- SpCurves
}
SpecaccumNat <- grid.arrange(grobs= list_plotsNat, nrow=2)
ggsave(SpecaccumNat, file=paste0(plot_dirSM, "/SpecaccumNat.jpg"), width=8, height=8)

# Complete survey data:
listSpecaccum <- lapply(listComms_mat, function(x) {x <- specaccum(x, method="random", permutations=500)})
listSpecaccum <- lapply(listSpecaccum, function(x) {x <- data.frame(cbind(x$sites, x$richness, x$sd))
names(x) <-c("Sites", "Richness", "Sd");x})

list_plots <- list()
for (i in 1:length(listSpecaccum)){
  dt <- listSpecaccum[[i]]
  x <- names(listSpecaccum)[[i]]
  SpCurves <- ggplot(data=dt, aes(y=Richness, x=Sites)) +
  geom_line() +
  #geom_point() +
  #geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = Richness-Sd, ymax = Richness+Sd),width = 0.2)+ # Seems to be OK? TBC
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymin=(Richness-2*Sd), ymax=(Richness+2*Sd)),alpha=0.2)+ # Does a bit of a weird thing for low levels of richness
  ylim(c(0,100))+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks=c(0,20,40,60,80,100), 
                   labels=c("0","20","40","60","80","100"))+
  labs(title=x)+
  theme_classic()+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    legend.title=element_text(size=14), 
    legend.text=element_text(size=12))
list_plots[[i]] <- SpCurves
}
SpecaccumComs <- grid.arrange(grobs= list_plots, nrow=2)
ggsave(SpecaccumComs, file=paste0(plot_dir, "/SpecaccumComs.jpg"), width=8, height=8)
```
<p>&nbsp;</p>
Figure 1. Species accumulation curves for the 53 sites surveyed across Central Mexico. Each panel represents the curve for a) the Historical Native Conservative Survey (i.e. only catalog records), b) the Historical Native Broad Survey (extension made by Pablo) computed with 500 permutations and obtained by adding sites in a random order. Verical lines represent the standard deviation around the mean. Curves generated using the function speaccum in the vegan package.
<p>&nbsp;</p>
Figure 2. Species accumulation curves for the 53 sites surveyed across Central Mexico. Each panel represents the curve for a) the Historical Conservative Scenario (i.e. only catalog records), b) the Historical Broad scenario (extension made by Pablo) & c) the Contemporary assemblage computed with 500 permutations and obtained by adding sites in a random order. Verical lines represent the standard deviation around the mean. Curves generated using the function speaccum in the vegan package.

__Interpretation: no curve reaches a plateau, indicating that it is likely that more species in the region would have been detected with sampling of additional sites.__

#### **Estimated gamma diversity (Survey data 53):**

```{r, echo=TRUE, results=TRUE}
# Historical native data:
listSpecpoolNat <- lapply(list_nat_mat, function(x){specpool(x)}) 
listSpecpoolNat <- do.call(rbind,listSpecpoolNat)
listSpecpoolNat %>%
  kbl() %>%
  kable_styling()

# Complete survey data:
listSpecpool <- lapply(listComms_mat, function(x){specpool(x)}) 
listSpecpool <- do.call(rbind,listSpecpool)
listSpecpool %>%
  kbl() %>%
  kable_styling()
```
<p>&nbsp;</p>
Table 1. Extrapolated gamma richness estimated using the reference data from each survey. The first column indicates the observed richness and the subsequent ones indicate the extrapolated mean richness & se computed with different indexes. HNC: Historical Native Conservative, HNB: Historical Native Broad. 
<p>&nbsp;</p>
Table 2. Extrapolated gamma richness estimated using the reference data from each survey. The first column indicates the observed richness and the subsequent ones indicate the extrapolated mean richness & se computed with different indexes. HC: Historical conservative, HB: Historical Broad & Cont: Contemporary. Estimators obtained with the function specpool in the vegan package.
<p>&nbsp;</p>

__Interpretation: even though the curves for each period are broadly similar, we can see how, for every index, the estimated mean gamma richness is lower for the contemporary period than for the historical periods. Our detected temporal trend toward spatial differentiation, if anything, goes in the opposite direction. Therefore, it is unlikely that it is explained by a sampling effect.__
